Generate QC parameter recommendations

Source: R/qc_utils.R
recommend_qc_parameters.Rd

Analyses the gene count distribution and provides detailed recommendations for quality control parameter settings using different stringency levels. Supports both dense and sparse matrices for efficient processing of large-scale single-cell datasets.

Usage

recommend_qc_parameters(gene_counts)

Arguments

gene_counts

A matrix of gene counts. Supports both standard and sparse matrices from the Matrix package.

Value

A list containing QC recommendations:

  • MAD_strategy: Conservative parameter settings based on median absolute deviation

  • Interval_90: Moderate parameter settings using 5th and 95th percentiles

  • Interval_80: Aggressive parameter settings using 10th and 90th percentiles

  • explanation: Descriptions of each approach

Examples

# Load example data
data(gene_counts_blood)

# Get QC recommendations
qc_recommendations <- recommend_qc_parameters(gene_counts_blood)


# View different strategies
print("MAD Strategy (Conservative):")
#> [1] "MAD Strategy (Conservative):"
print(qc_recommendations$MAD_strategy)
#> $min_genes_per_cell
#> [1] 980
#> 
#> $max_genes_per_cell
#> [1] 13756
#> 

print("\n90% Interval Strategy (Moderate):")
#> [1] "\n90% Interval Strategy (Moderate):"
print(qc_recommendations$Interval_90)
#> $min_genes_per_cell
#> [1] 4106
#> 
#> $max_genes_per_cell
#> [1] 10648
#> 

print("\n80% Interval Strategy (Aggressive):")
#> [1] "\n80% Interval Strategy (Aggressive):"
print(qc_recommendations$Interval_80)
#> $min_genes_per_cell
#> [1] 4474
#> 
#> $max_genes_per_cell
#> [1] 9663
#> 

# Use recommended parameters in create_scht
data(transcript_counts_blood)
data(transcript_info)
data(sample2stage)

scht_obj <- create_scht(
  gene_counts = gene_counts_blood,
  transcript_counts = transcript_counts_blood,
  transcript_info = transcript_info,
  cell_info = sample2stage,
  qc_params = c(
    qc_recommendations$MAD_strategy,
    list(
      min_cells_expressing = 0.02,
      min_expr = 1e-6
    )
  ),
  n_hvg = 3000,
  verbose = FALSE
)
#> 
#> === Sparsity Analysis for Current Dataset ===
#> 
#> 1. Original Transcript Matrix:
#>   Number of genes: 55,487
#>   Number of isoforms: 142,238
#>   Number of cells: 205
#>   Non-zero elements: 2,457,789
#>   Zero elements: 26,701,001
#>   Total elements: 29,158,790
#>   Sparsity: 91.57%
#> 
#> 2. Filtered Transcript Matrix (Post-QC HVG):
#>   Number of genes: 1,975
#>   Number of isoforms: 7,763
#>   Number of cells: 205
#>   Non-zero elements: 87,832
#>   Zero elements: 1,503,583
#>   Total elements: 1,591,415
#>   Sparsity: 94.48%
#> 
#> 3. SCHT Structure (Post-QC HVG):
#>   Non-zero elements: 87,832
#>   Zero elements: 199,972
#>   Total elements: 287,804
#>   Sparsity: 69.48%
#> 
#> 4. Naive 3D Tensor (Post-QC HVG):
#>   Required dimensions: 1,975 x 27 x 205
#>   Non-zero elements: 87,832
#>   Zero elements: 10,843,793
#>   Total elements: 10,931,625
#>   Sparsity: 99.20%
#> 
#> 5. Zero Elements Avoided by SCHT:
#>   vs Original Matrix: 26,501,029
#>   vs Filtered Matrix: 1,303,611
#>   vs Naive 3D Tensor: 10,643,821
#> 
#> 6. Memory Efficiency Summary:
#>   SCHT uses only 0.99% of original matrix size
#>   SCHT uses only 18.08% of filtered matrix size
#>   SCHT uses only 2.63% of naive tensor size
